docs.title: PySoundSphere
docs.text: PySoundSphere is a high level audio playback library written in python.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The installation process is straight forward. Most people will want to install the sounddevice backend. You can always install any backend later as well.

SounddevicePygameffplay Install with the sounddevice backend
pip install PySoundSphere[sounddevice-backend]
Install with the pygame backend
pip install PySoundSphere[pygame-backend]
Install with the ffplay backend
pip install PySoundSphere

docs.title: Getting started.
docs.text:
The following code is an example to get some audio playback started.

Getting it working
import PySoundSphere
import time

player = PySoundSphere.AudioPlayer("sounddevice")
player.load("path/to/your/audio_file")
player.volume = 0.025
player.play()

time.sleep(10)

docs.title: Choosing a backend
docs.text:
Make sure to have the backend you choose installed. Further instructions can be found here and here.

SounddevicePygameffplay Choose the sounddevice backend
import PySoundSphere
player = PySoundSphere.AudioPlayer("sounddevice")
Choose the pygame backend
import PySoundSphere
player = PySoundSphere.AudioPlayer("pygame")
Choose the ffplay backend
import PySoundSphere
player = PySoundSphere.AudioPlayer("ffplay")

docs.title: This backend should be seen as a fallback backend.
Due to limitations in ffplay volume can not be changed seamlessly, resulting in a minor stutter.
Installation
docs.text: On most systems no further installation is required. The ffplay backend only needs ffplay, which is part of ffmpeg. So make sure to have ffmpeg installed.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
The backend can be used like in the following.

Setup ffplay backend
import PySoundSphere
player = PySoundSphere.AudioPlayer("path/to/your/audio_file", "ffplay")

docs.title: What are playback backends?
docs.text: Playback backends determine which libraries will be used to actually play the sounds. PySoundSphere currently supports sounddevice, pygame and ffplay, with plans to later add support for PyAudio as well. Each backend has different requirements and different advantages/disadvantages.

docs.title: Which one should I use?
docs.text: Generally it is recommended to use sounddevice. If you encounter problems with it or you already use pygame somewhere in your project, it might be better to use that instead. ffplay is only meant as a fallback when nothing else works and thus should be avoided. There is more information on its dedicated page.

docs.title: How can I install them?
docs.text:
For each backend there is a dedicated page. Installation instructions can be found on there. Alternatively you will most likely have installed one backend during the installation PySoundSphere itself. Here are the links for all the dedicated pages:

  • sounddevice backend
  • sounddevice pygame
  • sounddevice ffplay

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The pygame backend is part of the optional dependency group pygame-backend. Either install it or install the required libraries manually.

AutomaticManual Install with the group
pip install PySoundSphere[pygame-backend]
Install the libraries manually
pip install PySoundSphere pygame

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
After that you can use the backend like in the following.

Setup pygame backend
import PySoundSphere
player = PySoundSphere.AudioPlayer("path/to/your/audio_file", "pygame")
